div.p: PROMETHEUS UNBOUND ACT 1
Bodleian MS. Shelley e.1,2,3

<ACT 1> Act 1 Scene--Night A Ravine of Icy Rocks in the Indian Caucasus. Prometheus is discovered bound to the precipice--Panthea & Ione are seated at his feet. {During the scene morning slowly breaks.}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
Monarch of Gods & DÃ¦mons & all Spirits
But One, who throng those bright & rolling Worlds
Which Thou & I alone of living things
Behold with sleepless eyes{ } regard this Earth
Made multitudinous with thy slaves, whom thou
Requitest for knee-worship, prayer & praise,
And toil, & hecatombs of broken hearts,
With fear & self contempt & barren hope;
Whilst me, who am thy foe, eyeless in hate,
Hast thou made reign & triumph, to thy scorn,
Oer mine own misery & thy vain revenge. . . .
Three thousand years of sleep-unsheltered hours
And moments, aye divided by keen pangs
Till they seem years, torture & solitude,
Scorn & despair--these are mine empire.
More glorious far than that which thou surveyest
From thine unenvied throne o Mighty God!
Almighty, had I deigned to share the shame
Of thine ill tyranny, and hung not here
Nailed to this wall of eagle baffling mountain
Black, wintry, dead, unmeasured{;} without herb
Insect or beast, or shape or sound of life--
Ah me, alas, pain, pain ever forever! {SB}
No change, no pause, no hope!--yet I endure
I ask the Earth, have not the mountains felt?
I ask yon Heaven--the all-beholding Sun
Has it not seen{?} the Sea, in storm or calm
Heaven's ever changing Shadow, spread below--
Have it's deaf waves not heard my agony?
Ah me alas pain ever forever {SB}
The crawling glaciers pierce me with the spears
Of their moon-freezing chrystals, the bright chains
Eat with their burning cold into my bones,
Heaven's winged hound, polluting from thy lips
His beak in poison not it's own, tears up
My heart; & shapeless sights come wandering by
The ghastly people of the realm of dream{,}
Mocking me & the Earthquake-fiends are charged
To wrench the rivets from my quivering wounds
When the rocks split & close again behind;
While from their loud abysses howling throng
The genii of the storm, urging the rage
Of whirlwind, & afflict me with keen hail.
And yet to me welcome is Day & Night
Whether one breaks the hoar frost of the morn,
Or starry, dim, & slow the other climbs
The leaden-coloured East; for then they lead
Thier wingless crawling Hours, one among whom{--}
--As some dark Priest hales the reluctant victim--
Shall drag thee, cruel King, to kiss the blood
From these pale feet, which then might trample thee
If they disdained not such a prostrate slave.--
Disdain? ah no I pity thee--what Ruin
Will hunt thee undefended thro wide Heaven!
How will thy soul, cloven to its depth with terror
Gape like a Hell within! I speak in grief
Not exultation, for I hate no more
As then, ere misery made me wise--the Curse
Once breathed on thee I would recall. Ye mountains
Whose many-voiced Echoes thro the mist
Of cataracts, flung the thunder of that spell;
Ye icy Springs stagnant with wrinkling frost
Which vibrated to hear me, & then crept
Shuddering through India; Thou serenest Air
Through which the Sun walks burning without beams,
And ye swift Whirlwinds who on poised wings
Hung mute & moveless oer yon hushed abyss
As thunder louder than your own made rock
The orbed world--if then my words had power,
--Though I am changed so that aught evil wish
Is dead within, although no memory be
Of what is hate--let them not lose it now!
What was that curse? for ye all heard me speak {SB}
{SD} FIRST VOICE: from the Mountains
Thrice three hundred thousand years
Oe'r the Earthquakes couch we stood;
Oft as men convulsed with fears
We trembled in our multitude. {SB}
{SD} SECOND VOICE: from the Springs
Thunderbolts had parched our water,
We had been stained with bitter blood
And had ran mute 'mid shrieks of slaugter
Thro' a city & a solitude! {SB}
{SD} THIRD VOICE: from the Air
I had clothed since Earth uprose
Its wastes in colours not their own,
And oft had my serene repose
Been cloven by many a rending groan {SB} And silence
{SD} FOURTH VOICE: from the Whirlwinds
We had soared beneath these mountains
Unresting ages;--nor had thunder
Nor yon Volcano's flaming fountains
Nor any power above or under,
Ever made us mute with wonder! {SB}
{SD} FIRST VOICE
But never bowed our snowy crest
As at the voice of thine unrest-- {SB}
{SD} SECOND VOICE
Never such a sound before
To the Indian waves we bore.--
A pilot asleep on the howling sea
Leaped up from the deck in agony
And heard, & cried--ah woe is me!
And died as mad as the wild waves be {SB}
{SD} THIRD VOICE
By such dread words from Earth to Heaven
My still realm was never riven
When its wound was closed, there stood
Darkness oer the Day{,} like blood. {SB}
{SD} FOURTH VOICE
And we shrank back--for dreams of ruin
To frozen caves our flight pursuing
Made us keep silence--thus--& thus--
Though silence is as hell to us {SB} they pass with a terrible sound
{SD} THE EARTH
The tongueless caverns of the craggy hills
Cried Misery, then the hollow Heaven replied
Misery! And the Oceans purple waves,
Climbing the land, howled to the lashing winds.
And the pale nations heard it,--Misery! {SB}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
I hear a sound of voices--not the voice
Which I gave forth.--Mother thy sons & thou
Scorn him, without whose all-enduring will
Beneath the fierce omnipotence of Jove
Both they & thou had vanished like thin mist
Unrolled on the morning wind!--Know ye not me
The Titan, he who made his agony
The barrier to your else all conquering foe?
O rock-embosomed Lawn{s} & snow-fed stream{s}
Now seen athwart frore vapours deep below,
Thro whose oer-shadowing woods I wandered once
With Asia, drinking life from her loved eyes,
Why scorns the spirit which informs ye, now
To commune with me--me alone, who checked--
As one who checks a fiend-drawn charioteer--
The falshood & the force of Him who reigns
Supreme, & with the groans of pining slaves
Fills your dim glens & liquid wildernesses?
Why answer ye not, still? brethren! {SB} {HL}
{SD} THE EARTH
They dare not {SB}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
Who dares? for I would hear that curse again. . . .
Ha, what an awful whisper rises up!
'Tis scarce like sound, it tingles thro the frame
As lightning tingles, hovering ere it strike--
Speak Spirit! from thine inorganic voice
I only know that thou art moving near
And love. How cursed I him? {SB} {HL}
{SD} THE EARTH
How canst thou hear
Who knowest not the language of the dead? {SB}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
Thou art a living spirit--speak as they {SB}
{SD} THE EARTH
I dare not speak like life, lest Heaven's fierce King
Should hear, & link me to some wheel of pain
More torturing than the one whereon I roll.--
Subtle thou art & good, & tho' the Gods
Hear not this voice--yet thou art more than God
Being wise & kind--earnestly hearken now-- {SB}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
Obscurely through my brain like shadows dim
Sweep awful thoughts rapid & thick--I feel
Faint, like one mingled in entwining love,
Yet 'tis not pleasure {SB} {HL}
{SD} THE EARTH
No, thou canst not hear
Thou art immortal, & this tongue is known
Only to those who die . . . {SB} {HL}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
{And what art thou}
{O melancholy Voice?} {SB} {HL}
{SD} THE EARTH
I am the Earth
Thy mother, she within whose stony veins
To the last fibre of the loftiest tree
Whose thin leaves trembled in the frozen air
Joy ran, as blood within a living frame
When thou didst from her bosom, like a beam
From sunrise, leap--a spirit of keen joy!
And at thy voice her pining sons uplifted
Their prostrate brows from the polluting dust
And our invisible Tyrant with fierce dread
Grew pale--until his thunder chained thee here--
Then--see those million worlds which burn & roll
Around us; their inhabitants beheld
My sphered light wane in wide Heaven, the sea
Was lifted with strange tempest, & new fire
From earthquake-rifted mountains of bright snow
Shook its portentous hair beneath Heaven's frown;
Lightning & Inundation vexed the plains
Blue thistles bloomed in cities; foodless toads
Within voluptuous chambers panting crawled;
When Plague had fallen on man & beast & worm
And Famine, & black blight on herb & tree,
And in the corn, & vines & meadow grass
Teemed ineradicable poisonous weeds
Draining their growth, for my wan breast was dry
With grief, & the thin air, my breath, was stained
With the contagion of a mothers hate
Breathed on her child's destroyer--aye, I heard
Thy curse, the which if thou rememberst not
Yet my innumerable seas & streams
Mountains & caves & winds, & yon wide Air
And the inarticulate people of the dead
Preserve, a treasured spell. We meditate
In secret joy & hope those dreadful words
But dare not speak them {SB} {HL}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
Venerable Mother!
All else who live & suffer take from thee
Some comfort; flowers & fruits & happy sounds
And love, though fleeting; these may not be mine
But mine own words, I pray, deny me not {SB}
{SD} THE EARTH
They shall be told--. Ere Babylon was dust
The Magus Zoroaster, my dead child
Met his own image walking in the garden,
That apparition, sole of men, he saw.
For know there are two worlds of life & death
One that which thou beholdest, but the other
Is underneath the grave, where do inhabit
The shadows of all forms that think & live
Till death unite them, and they part no more,
Dreams & the light imaginings of men
And all that faith creates, or love desires,
Terrible, strange, sublime & beauteous shapes.
There thou art, & dost hang, a writhing shade
'Mid whirlwind-shaken mountains; all the Gods
Are there, & all the Powers of nameless worlds
Vast, sceptered Phantoms; heroes, men, & beasts
And Demogorgon, a tremendous Gloom
And he, the Supreme Tyrant on his throne throned
On burning Gold. Son one of these shall utter
The curse which all remember. Call at will
Thine own ghost, or the ghost of Jupiter,
Hades, or Typhon or what mightier Gods
From all-prolific evil, since thy ruin
Have sprung, & trampled on my prostrate sons--
Ask & they must reply--so the revenge
Of the supreme may sweep through vacant shades
As rainy wind through the abandoned gate
Of a fallen palace {SB} {HL}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
Mother, let not aught
Of that which may be evil, pass again
My lips, or those of aught resembling me--
Phantasm of Jupiter arise appear! {SB}
{SD} IONE
My wings are folded oer mine ears,
My wings are crossed over mine eyes,
Yet thro their silver shade appears
And through their lulling plumes arise
A Shape, a throng of sounds:
May it be, no ill to thee
O thou of many wounds
Near whom for our sweet sister's sake
Ever thus we watch & wake {SB}
{SD} PANTHEA
The sound is of whirlwind underground
Earthquake & fire & mountains cloven,
The Shape is awful like the sound,
Clothed in dark purple star-inwoven
A sceptre of pale gold
To stay steps proud, oer the slow cloud
Its His veined hand doth hold
Cruel it he looks but calm & strong
Like one who does, not suffers wrong {SB}
{SD} PHANTASM OF JUPITER
Why have the secret powers of this strange world
Driven me, a frail & empty phantom hither
On direst storms? What unaccustomed sounds
Are hovering on my lips unlike the voice
With which our pallid race hold ghastly talk
In darkness? and proud Sufferer who art thou? {SB}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
Tremendous image, as thou art must be
Him whom thou shadowest forth. I am his foe
The Titan. speak the words which I would hear
Although no thought inform thine empty voice {SB}
{SD} THE EARTH
Listen! and though your echoes must be mute
Grey mountains & old woods & haunted springs
Prophetic caves & isle-surrounding streams
Rejoice to hear what yet ye dare not speak {SB}
{SD} PHANTASM
A spirit seizes me, & speaks within
It tears me as fire tears a thunder-cloud! {SB}
{SD} PANTHEA
{See} how he lifts his mighty looks, the Heaven
Darkens above. {SB} {HL}
{SD} IONE
He speaks! O shelter me-- {SB}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
I see the curse on gestures proud & cold
And looks of firm defiance, & calm hate
And such despair as mocks itself with smiles
Written as on a scroll . . . yet speak--o speak. . {SB}
{SD} PHANTASM
Fiend I defy thee, with a calm fixed mind
All that thou canst inflict I bid thee do
Foul Tyrant both of Gods & Humankind
One only being shalt thou not subdue
Rain then thy plagues upon me here
Ghastly disease & frenzying fear
And let alternate frost & fire
Eat into me, & be thine ire
Lightning & cutting hail and legioned forms
Of furies, driving by upon the wounding storms {SB}
Aye do thy worst. Thou art Omnipotent
Oer all things but thy self I gave thee power
And my own will. Be thy swift mischiefs sent
To blast mankind from yon etherial tower
Let thy malignant spirit move
Its darkness over those I love:
On me & mine I imprecate
The utmost torture of thy hate
And thus devote to sleepless agony
This undeclining head while thou must reign on high {SB}
But thou who art the God & Lord--o thou
Who fillest with thy soul this world of woe
To whom all things of Earth & Heaven do bow
In fear & worship--all-prevailing foe!
I curse thee! let a sufferer's curse
Clasp thee, his torturer, like remorse,
'Till thine Infinity shall be
A robe of envenomed agony
And thine Omnipotence a crown of pain
To cling like burning gold round thy dissolving brain. {SB}
Heap on thy soul by virtue of this Curse
Ill deeds, then be thou damned, beholding good
Both infinite as is this Universe
And thou, & thy self torturing solitude.
An awful Image of calm power
Though now thou s{i}ttest, let the hour
Come, when thou must appear to be
That which thou art internally
And after many a false & fruitless crime
Scorn track thy lagging fall thro boundless {S}pace & time. {SB}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
Were these my words o Parent? {SB} {HL}
{SD} THE EARTH
They were thine {SB}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
It doth repent me: words are quick & vain;
Grief for awhile is blind, & so was mine
I wish no living thing to suffer pain. {SB}
{SD} THE EARTH
Misery o misery to me
That Jove at length should vanquish thee
Wail, howl aloud Land & Sea
The Earths rent heart shall answer ye
Howl spirits of the living & the dead
Your refuge, your defence lies fallen & vanquished {SB}
{SD} FIRST ECHO
Lies Fallen & vanquished? {SB}
{SD} SECOND ECHO
Fallen & vanquished! {SB}
{SD} IONE
Fear not--tis but some passing spasm
The Titan is unvanquished still.
But see, where thro the azure chasm
Of yon forked & snowy hill
Trampling the slant winds on high
With golden-sandalled feet, that glow
Under plumes of purple dye
Like rose-ensanguined ivory
A Shape comes now
Stretching on high from his right hand
A serpent-cinctured wand {SB}
{SD} PANTHEA
Tis Jove's world-wandering Herald, Mercury {SB}
{SD} IONE
And who are those with hydra tresses
And iron wings that climb the wind
Whom the frowning God represses
Like vapours steaming up behind,
Clanging loud, an endless crowd {SB}
{SD} PANTHEA
These are Joves tempest-walking hounds
Whom he gluts on groans & blood
When charioted on sulphurous cloud
He bursts Heaven's bounds {SB}
{SD} IONE
Are they now led from the thin dead
On new pangs to be fed? {SB}
{SD} PANTHEA
Yes {:} but The Titan looks as ever firm, not proud. {SB}
{SD} FIRST FURY
Ha I scent life{!--} {SB} {HL}
{SD} SECOND FURY
Let me but look in his eyes! {SB}
{SD} THIRD FURY
The hope of torturing him smells like a heap
Of corpses To a death-bird after battle! {SB}
{SD} FIRST FURY
Darest thou delay o Herald! take cheer Hounds
Of Hell--what if the Son of Maia soon
Should make us food & sport? Who can please long
The Omnipotent? {SB} {HL}
{SD} MERCURY
Back to your towers of iron
And gnash, beside the streams of fire{. .} & wail
Your foodless teeth! . . Geryon arise & Gorgon
ChimÃ¦ra & thou Spinx subtlest of fiends
Who ministered to Thebes Heaven's poisoned wine
Unnatural love & more unnatural hate
These shall perform your task {SB} {HL}
{SD} FIRST FURY
O mercy{!} mercy
We die with our desire--drive us not back! {SB}
{SD} MERCURY
Crouch then in silence.-- {SB} {HL}
Awful Sufferer{,}
To thee unwilling, most unwillingly
I come{,} by the great Father's will driven down
To execute a doom of new revenge.
Alas I pity thee, and hate myself
That I can do more--aye from thy sight
Returning, for a season, heaven seems hell{.}
So thy worn form pursues me night & day,
Smiling reproach. Wise art thou firm & go{od}
But vanily wouldst stand forth alone in strife
Against the Omnipotent, as yon clear lamps
That measure & divide the weary years
From which there is no refuge, long have taught
And long must teach--even now thy Torturer arms
with the strange might of unimagined pains
The powers who scheme slow agonies in hell,
And my commission is{,} to lead them here
Or what more subtle foul & savage fiends
People the abyss, & leave them to their task.
Be it not so . . . there is a secret known
To thee & to none else of living things
Which may transfer the sceptre of wide Heaven
The fear of which perplexes the Supreme. . .
Clothe it in words, & bid it clasp his throne
In intercession; bend thy soul in prayer
And like a suppliant in some gorgeous fane
Let the will kneel within thy haughty heart;
For benefits & meek submission tame
The fiercest & the mightiest. {SB} {HL}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
Evil minds
Change good to their own nature. I gave all
He has{;}--& in return he chains me here
Years, ages night & day, whether the Sun
Split my parched skin, or in the moony {night--}
The chrystal-winged snow cling round my hair--
Whilst my beloved race is trodden down
By his thought-executing ministers.
Such is the tyrants recompense--'tis just:
He who is evil can recieve no good
And for a world bestowed or a friend lost
He Can feel hate, fear, shame--not gratitude
He but requites me for his own misdeed{;}
Kindness to such is keen reproach which breaks
With bitter stings the light sleep of Revenge.
Submission, thou dost know, I cannot try:
For what submission but that fatal word
The death-seal of mankind's captivity,
Like the Sicilians hair-suspended sword
Which trembles oer his crown, would he accept{--}
Or could I yield?--which yet I will not yield.
Let others flatter Crime where it sits thron{e}d
In brief Omnipotence; secure are they
For Justice when triumphant will weep down
Pity not punishment on her own wrongs
Too much avenged by those who err. I wait
Enduring thus the retributive hour
Which since we spake is even nearer now--
But hark the hell-hounds clamour, fear delay
Behold Heaven lowers under thy Father's frown. {SB}
{SD} MERCURY
O that we might be spared--I to inflict
And thou to suffer! once more answer me
Thou knowest not the period of Joves power? {SB}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
I know but this, that it must come {SB} {HL}
{SD} MERCURY
alas,
Thou canst not count thy years to come of pain? {SB}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
They last while Jove must reign, nor more nor less
Do I desire or fear{.} {SB} {HL}
{SD} MERCURY
Yet pause, & plunge
Into Eternity, where recorded time
Even all that we imagine, age on age
Seems but a point, and the reluctant mind
Flags wearily in its' unending flight
Till it sink, dizzy, blind, lost, shelterless;
Perchance it has not numbered the slow years
Which thou must spend in torture, unreprieved. {SB}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
Perchance no thought can count them--yet they pass {SB}
{SD} MERCURY
If thou might'st dwell among the Gods the while
Lapped in voluptuous joy?-- {SB} {HL}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
I would not quit
This bleak ravine, these unrepentant pains {SB}
{SD} MERCURY
Alas I wonder at, yet pity thee {SB}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
Pity the self-despising slaves of Heaven
Not me, within whose mind sits peace serene
As light in the sun, throned . . . how vain is talk!
Call up the fiends {SB} {HL}
{SD} IONE
O sister O sister look, white fire
Has cloven to the roots yon huge snow-loaded Cedar
How fearfully God's thunder howls behind! {SB}
{SD} MERCURY
I must obey his words & thine--alas
Most heavily remorse hangs at my heart! {SB}
{SD} PANTHEA
See where the child of Heaven with winged feet
Runs down the slanted sunlight of the dawn {SB}
{SD} IONE
Dear sister close thy plumes over thine eyes
Lest thou behold & die--they come they come
Blackening the birth of day with countless wings
And hollow underneath like death {SB} {HL}
{SD} FIRST FURY
Prometheus! {SB}
{SD} SECOND FURY
Immortal Titan! {SB} {HL}
{SD} THIRD FURY
Champion of Heaven's slaves! {SB}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
He whom some dreadful voice invokes, is here,
Prometheus, the chained Titan.--Horrible forms
What & who are ye? never yet there came
Phantasms so foul thro monster-teeming Hell
From the all-miscreative brain of Jove;
Whilst I behold such execrable shapes{. .}
Methinks I grow like what I contemplate
And laugh & stare in loathsome sympathy {SB}
{SD} FIRST FURY
We are the ministers of pain & fear
And dissappointment & mistrust & hate
And clinging crime; & as lean dogs pursue
Through wood & lake some struck & sobbing fawn
We track all things that weep & bleed & live
When the great King betrays them to our will {SB}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
O many fearful natures in one name!
I know ye, & these lakes & echoes know
The darkness & the clangour of your wings.
But why more hideous than your loathed selves
Gather ye up in legions from the deep? {SB}
{SD} SECOND FURY
We knew not that--Sisters rejoice rejoice! {SB}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
Can aught exult in its deformity? {SB}
{SD} SECOND FURY
The beauty of delight makes lovers glad
Gazing on one another--so are we{.} .
As from the rose which the pale priestess kneels
To gather for her festal crown of flowers
The aerial crimson falls, flushing her cheek--
So from our victim's destined agony
The shade which is our form invests us round
Else are we shapeless as our Mother {N}ight {SB}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
I laugh your power & his who sent you here
To lowest scorn.--pour forth the cup of pain {SB}
{SD} FIRST FURY
Thou thinkest we will rend thee bone from bone?
And nerve from nerve, working like fire within? {SB}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
Pain is my element as hate is thine
Ye rend me now, I care not-- {SB} {HL}
{SD} SECOND FURY
Dost imagine
We will but laugh into thy lidless eyes? {SB}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
I weigh not what ye do, but what ye suffer
Being evil--cruel was the Power which called
You, or aught else so wretched, into light {SB}
{SD} THIRD FURY
Thou think{e'}st we will live through thee, one by one
Like animal life and though we can obscure not
The soul which burns within that we will dwell
Beside it, like a vain loud multitude
Vexing the self-content of wisest men--
That we will be dread thought beneath thy brain
And foul desire round thine astonished heart
And blood within thy labyrithine veins
Crawling like agony {SB} {HL}
{SD} PROMETHEUS
Why, ye are thus now
Yet am I king over myself & rule
The torturing & conflicting throngs within
As Jove rules you when Hell grows mutinous {SB}
{SD} CHORUS OF FURIES
From the ends of the Earth, from {ye} ends of the Earth
Where the night has its grave & the morning its birth
Come, Come, Come
O ye who shake hills with the scream of your mirth
When cities sink howling in ruin, & ye
Who with wingless footsteps trample the Sea
And close upon Shipwreck & Famines track
Sit chattering with joy on the foodless wreck
Come, Come, Come!
Leave the bed, low cold & red
Strewed beneath a nation dead;
Leave the hatred--as in ashes
Fire is left for future burning,--
It will burst in bloodier flashes
When ye stir it soon returning;
Leave the self contempt implanted
In young spirits sense-{e}nchanted
Misery's yet unkindled fuel;
Leave Hells' secrets half-unchanted
To the maniac dreamer: cruel
More than ye can be with hate,
Is he with fear.
Come, Come come!
We are steaming up from Hells wide gate
And we burthen the blasts of the atmosphere
But vainly we toil till ye come here {SB}
{SD} IONE
Sister I hear the thunder of new wings {SB}
{SD} PANTHEA
These solid mountains quiver with the sound
Even as the tremulous air--Thier shadows make
The space within my plumes more black than night. {SB}
{SD} FIRST FURY
Your call was as a winged car
Driven on whirlwinds fast & far
It rapt us from from red gulphs of war {SB}
{SD} SECOND FURY
From wide cities famine-wasted-- {SB}
{SD} THIRD FURY
Groans half heard, & blood untasted-- {SB}
{SD} FOURTH FURY
Kingly conclaves stern & cold
Where blood with gold was bought & sold {SB}
{SD} FIFTH FURY
From the furnace white & hot
In which-- {SB} {HL}
{SD} A FURY
Speak not--whisper not
I know all that ye would tell
But to speak might break the spell
Which must bend the Invincible
The stern of thought
He yet defies the deepest power of Hell {SB}
{SD} a FURY rushing from the crowd
Tear the veil{!--} {SB} {HL} The Furies having {?mingled} in a strange dance divide, & in the background is seen a plain covered with burning cities
{SD} ANOTHER FURY
It is torn! {SB} {HL}
{SD} CHORUS
The pale stars of the morn
Shine on a misery dire to be born{e}
Dost thou faint mighty Titan? We laugh thee to scorn
Dost thou boast the clear knowledge thou wakenedst for man?
Then was kindled within him a thirst which outran
Those perishing waters, a thirst of fierce fever
Hope love doubt desire--which consume him forever.
One came forth, of gentle worth
Smiling on the sanguine earth,
His words outlived him, like swift poison
Withering up truth peace & pity
Look where round the wide horizon
Many a million-peopled city
Vomits smoke in the bright air-- {a shadow passes over the scene & a piercing shriek is heard}
Hark that outcry of despair
Tis his mild & gentle ghost

In each human heart terror survives

{SD} CHORUS OF SPIRITS
From unremembered ages we
Gentle guides & guardians be
Of Heaven-oppressed mortality--
And we breathe, & sicken not,
The atmosphere of human thought:
Be it dim & dank & grey
Like a storm-extinguished day
Travelled oer by dying gleams;
Be it bright as all between
Cloudless skies & windless streans
Silent liquid & serene--
As the birds within the wind
As the fish within the wave
As the thoughts of man's own mind
Float through all above the grave
We make there, our liquid lair
Voyaging cloudlike & unpent
Thro the boundless element--
Thence we bear the prophecy
Which begins & ends in thee! {SB}
{SD} IONE

{SD} FIRST SPIRIT
On a battle-trumpet's blast
I fled hither fast fast fast
Mid the darkness upward cast--
From the dust of creeds outworn
From the tyrants banner torn
Gathering round me, onward borne
There was mingled many a cry
Freedom, Hope, Death Victory!
Till they faded thro the sky
And one sound, above around
One sound beneath around above
Was moving; twas the soul of love
Twas the hope the prophecy
Which begins & ends in thee {SB}
{SD} SECOND SPIRIT
A rainbows arch stood on the sea
Which rocked beneath, immoveably;
And the triumphant Storm did flee
Like a conqueror swift & proud,
Between{,} with many a captive cloud
A shapeless dark & rapid crowd
Each by lightning riven in half--
I heard the thunder hoarsely laugh--
Mighty fleets were strewn like chaff
And spread beneath, a hell of death
Oer the white waters--I alit
On a great ship lightning-split
And speeded hither on the sigh
Of one who gave an enemy
His plank--then plunged aside to die {SB}
{SD} THIRD SPIRIT
I sate beside a sage's bed
And the lamp was burning red
Near the book where he had fed
When a dream with plumes of flame
To his pillow hovering came
And I knew it was the same
Which had kindled long ago
Pity eloquence & woe
And the world awhile below
Wore the shade, its lustre made
It has borne me here as fleet
As Desires lightning feet
I must ride it back ere morrow
Or the sage will wake in sorrow {SB}
{SD} FOURTH SPIRIT
On a Poets lips I slept
Dreaming like a love-adept
In the sound his breathing kept;
Nor seeks nor finds he mortal blisses
But feeds on the aerial kisses
Of shapes that haunt thoughts wilderness
He will watch from dawn to gloom
The lake-reflected Sun illume
The yellow bees in the ivy-bloom
Nor heed nor see, what things they be
But from these create he can
Forms more real than living man
Nurslings of immortality!--
One of these awakened me
And I sped to succour thee {SB}

{SD} FIFTH SPIRIT
As over wide dominions

{SD} SIXTH SPIRIT
